awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  The Effects of Process Facilitation on Emotion Regulation
awd_abstract_narration:
We can try to change our emotions by changing our thoughts, but sometimes this is not successful.  This CAREER project tests the innovative prediction that certain thoughts engage neural processes to improve our ability to regulate emotions under certain conditions. The researcher, Dr. Kateri McRae, at the University of Denver, will examine whether what a person is doing and what parts of their brain are most active, just before changing their thinking, will matter. When a task uses cognitive processes that overlap with brain regions used during emotion regulation, then the regulation that follows will be easier and more effective. The educational portion of the CAREER projects has two parts. First, undergraduate students will partner with community members to develop multimedia resources about emotions and emotion regulation that will be available via the internet. Second, outreach to the community and underrepresented students will focus on teaching them about making valid conclusions from psychological science, and learning what neuroscience measures in particular can tell us. The potential benefits of this project include discovering the conditions that allow people to manage their emotions. Benefits also include educating a large community about emotion regulation, neuroscience, and the scientific method.

The central hypothesis of this CAREER proposal is that overlapping cognitive and neural processes pave a path for emotion regulation by enhancing cognitive reappraisal. Central to this hypothesis is that rather than being passive victims of their emotions, people have tools they can use to influence their emotions. This project tests the hypothesis that three cognitive processes facilitate subsequent emotion regulation. The first process involves our brains' tendency to resolve conflict quickly and efficiently. This project examines the effects of cognitive processes involved in emotional conflict resolution. The second process is decreasing self-focus and thus emotional responses. The third process involves top-down emotion generation, such as that generated via language or rich narratives. Validated experimental manipulations are used with multiple measures of affect across six laboratory experiments. Each of the three candidate processes will be manipulated in their own study. Psychophysiological measures (e.g., electrodermal activity, heart rate, respiration) and self-reports will be used, and their effects on cognitive reappraisal examined. Three fMRI neuroimaging studies (one per process) will test the hypothesis that overlapping neural processes characterize effective precursors of cognitive reappraisal.  Lastly, a large-scale neuroimaging analysis will collapse across the three fMRI studies to identify brain regions that are common to successful cognitive reappraisal across contexts. The educational dissemination plan includes having undergraduate students work with community members to develop multimedia presentations, and discussing neuroscience research methods focusing on valid and accurate conclusions.  The implications include a better understanding of processes that lead to efficient emotion regulation, thereby enhancing personal well-being and productivity. The implications also include facilitating better understanding of psychological science across a variety of populations.

por.por_cntn:
Although emotions are often helpful, it is adaptive for mental health to be able to regulate your emotions in accordance with your goals. Cognitive reappraisal, or changing your thoughts in order to change your feelings, is considered a largely effective emotion regulation strategy. However, it does require effortful cognitive resources, and reliably engages prefrontal and parietal cortices. In a series of studies, we tested competing hypotheses about the effects of engaging in psychological processes thought to overlap in the brain with reappraisal processes, immediately before (or during) engaging in reappraisal. According to process facilitation theories, engaging in these overlapping processes might facilitate reappraisal. According to process depletion accounts, engaging in overlapping processes might impair reappraisal. We hoped to test these competing hypotheses, with the prediction that engaging in overlapping processing might be faciliatory.

In a series of studies, we did not find converging evidence for process-specific facilitation – that is, engaging in overlapping processes did not uniquely boost reappraisal ability. Replicating multiple previous studies, we did observe robust effects of cognitive reappraisal compared to a non-regulation condition, with reappraisal resulting in lower negative emotion in accordance with instructed goals. However, across studies using several different manipulations, we did not observe even lower ratings of negative affect during reappraisal as a result of any of our experimental manipulations. Unexpectedly, we did observe some effects of overlapping processes on self-reported negative emotion in the non-regulation condition. In other words, when people were not actively trying to use reappraisal to regulate their negative emotions, having recently engaged in a conflict resolution trial in an emotional Stroop, or having recently engaged in cognitive reappraisal on the previous trial, significantly decreased self-reported negative emotion. Therefore, engaging in processes that overlap with reappraisal may decrease negative emotion when people are not intending to regulate, but do not seem to further facilitate effortful, instructed reappraisal.

This award also led to other important findings. While studying the social aspects of reappraisal, we observed that students were in more frequent contact with people they were more likely to endorse as providing social reappraisal support. This effect was true across modality (in-person, text, video), which is critical considering data were collected during some of the most restrictive phases of the COVID-19 response in 2020. In a separate study, to follow up on previously observed gender differences, we tested the effects of positive cognitive reappraisal on decision-making, and found a remarkably strong moderation by gender. Specifically, we observed significant facilitation of performance on the Iowa Gambling Task (IGT) when women were alternating between the IGT and positive reappraisal, but significant impairment on the task in men who were alternating between the IGT and positive reappraisal. We also began to develop an individual difference measure that uses self-report to examine the degree to which people experience emotions generated from more environmental (bottom-up) or more cognitive (top-down) sources. Finally, advanced neuroimaging analyses identified some regions of the brain which were engaged by reappraisal in multiple studies. We believe these findings will all open fruitful avenues for future research on contextual and individual difference factors which influence the success and adaptive outcomes associated with reappraisal. Given that reappraisal is a core part of empirically supported therapies for treating mental illness, knowing when and for whom reappraisal is most likely to work well has the potential to improve therapeutic outcomes in a variety of settings.
